headline: Sources and acknowledgments

children.data: In addition to those quoted, the author would like to thank the numerous analysts, journalists, diplomats and officials who preferred to be interviewed on background, or whose thoughts and writing helped shape this report.
The Nation or the Ummah: Islamism and Turkish Foreign Policy
”. By Birol Bakan and Omer Taspinar
Media in New Turkey: The Origins of an Authoritarian Neoliberal State
Turkey Under Erdogan: How a Country Turned from Democracy and the West
Turkey’s Mission Impossible: War and Peace with the Kurds
The Remaking of Republican Turkey: Memory and Modernity since the Fall of the Ottoman Empire
Why Turkey is Authoritarian: From Ataturk to Erdogan

bodyText:
In addition to those quoted, the author would like to thank the numerous analysts, journalists, diplomats and officials who preferred to be interviewed on background, or whose thoughts and writing helped shape this report. 
Recommended reading and sources:
“The Nation or the Ummah: Islamism and Turkish Foreign Policy”. By Birol Bakan and Omer Taspinar
“Media in New Turkey: The Origins of an Authoritarian Neoliberal State”. By Bilge Yesil
“Turkey Under Erdogan: How a Country Turned from Democracy and the West”. By Dimitar Bechev
“Abdulhamid II : Le sultan calife”. By François Georgeon
“Turkey’s Mission Impossible: War and Peace with the Kurds”. By Cengiz Candar
“The Remaking of Republican Turkey: Memory and Modernity since the Fall of the Ottoman Empire”. By Nicholas Danforth
“Why Turkey is Authoritarian: From Ataturk to Erdogan”. By Halil Karaveli

parts.headline: Sources and acknowledgments

parts.description: As video games move from teenage distraction to universal pastime they are following the same path as other mass media, says Tom Wainwright

parts.headline: Ready, player four billion: the rise of video games
parts.description: As video games move from teenage distraction to universal pastime they are following the path of other mass media, says Tom Wainwright

parts.headline: Battles over streaming break out for video games
parts.description: Streaming subscriptions have revolutionised music and television. What will they do to games?

parts.headline: Moviemaking and gamemaking are converging
parts.description: But game developers have a better business model than Hollywood

publication.headline: Erdogan’s empire
publication.description: Approaching its centenary, Turkey faces an election that could decide its future as a democracy, argues Piotr Zalewski

parts.headline: Turkey faces a crucial election this summer
parts.description: Approaching its centenary, the country prepares for an election that could decide its future as a democracy, argues Piotr Zalewski

parts.headline: The Turkish economy is in pressing need of reform and repair
parts.description: A bizarre monetary policy has left an economy in need of urgent repair

parts.headline: Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s relatives are becoming increasingly powerful
parts.description: A government over-reliant on kith and kin

parts.headline: The effects on Turkey of Syria’s civil war
parts.description: The war has redrawn Turkey’s political map

parts.headline: Turkey has given up promoting political Islam abroad
parts.description: Recep Tayyip Erdogan is mending fences with his Arab neighbours

parts.headline: Turkey has a newly confrontational foreign policy
parts.description: The country has turned into an awkward ally for the West

parts.headline: The Turkish opposition faces big obstacles to winning the election
parts.description: They remain rudderless

parts.headline: Turkey is still just a democracy, but it is not certain to remain that way
parts.description: The election will test the country’s democratic credentials

parts.description: How we saw the world

parts.headline: Disney’s troubles show how technology has changed the business of culture
parts.description: At 100, the mouse can still roar. But it faces a new kind of rival

parts.headline: Turkey could be on the brink of dictatorship
parts.description: President Erdogan could tip his country over the edge

parts.headline: Excess deaths are soaring as health-care systems wobble
parts.description: What lessons can be learned from a miserable winter across the rich world?

parts.headline: South Africa’s collapsing railway company is a cautionary tale
parts.description: A “developmental state” is less useful than keeping the lights on and trains running

parts.headline: How to sell to the young
parts.subheadline: Don’t try to dig what we all say
parts.description: A myth-busting memo for your boss

_metadata.title: Turkey - Sources and acknowledgments | Special report | The Economist
_metadata.headline: Sources and acknowledgments
author: The Economist
_metadata.articleBody:
In addition to those quoted, the author would like to thank the numerous analysts, journalists, diplomats and officials who preferred to be interviewed on background, or whose thoughts and writing helped shape this report. 
Recommended reading and sources:
“The Nation or the Ummah: Islamism and Turkish Foreign Policy”. By Birol Bakan and Omer Taspinar
“Media in New Turkey: The Origins of an Authoritarian Neoliberal State”. By Bilge Yesil
“Turkey Under Erdogan: How a Country Turned from Democracy and the West”. By Dimitar Bechev
“Abdulhamid II : Le sultan calife”. By François Georgeon
“Turkey’s Mission Impossible: War and Peace with the Kurds”. By Cengiz Candar
“The Remaking of Republican Turkey: Memory and Modernity since the Fall of the Ottoman Empire”. By Nicholas Danforth
“Why Turkey is Authoritarian: From Ataturk to Erdogan”. By Halil Karaveli
